elements.content: Removal of xenon (Xe) and krypton (Kr) from process off-gases containing 400 ppm Xe, 40 ppm Kr, 78% N2, 21% O2, 0.9% Ar, 0.03% CO2, and so forth using adsorption was demonstrated for the first time. Two well-known metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), HKUST-1 and Ni/DOBDC, which both have unsaturated metal centers but different pore morphologies, were selected as novel adsorbents. Results of an activated carbon were also included for comparison. The Ni/DOBDC has higher Xe/Kr selectivities than those of the activated carbon and the HKUST-1. In addition, results show that the Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1 can adsorb substantial amounts of Xe and Kr even when they are mixed in air. Moreover, the Ni/DOBDC can successfully separate 400 ppm Xe from 40 ppm Kr and air containing O2, N2, and CO2 with a Xe/Ke selectivity of 7.3 as indicated by our breakthrough results. This shows a promising future for MOFs in radioactive nuclide separations from spent fuels.

To do this, the current method is to install and operate a cryogenic process, which is very energy-intensive. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Separating low concentrations of xenon (Xe) and krypton (Kr) from air is an important step in removing radioactive 85Kr from spent nuclear fuels. To do this, the current method is to install and operate a cryogenic process, which is very energy-intensive. In contrast, separation of Xe and Kr by selective adsorption near room temperature would be more energy efficient. There are several examples in the literature in which zeolites and activated carbons have been tested for Xe/Kr separation. Previous research has shown NaA and NaX zeolites to be selective adsorbents for Xe over Kr with selectivities of approximately four to six, but with low capacities.

elements.content: Therefore, it is necessary to find some alternative adsorbents that can adsorb large amount of Xe and Kr, especially at low concentrations. Thus, MOFs represent a new class of functional materials consisting of metal centers linked with organic building blocks to produce diverse and customizable structural frameworks. These materials could augment the existing technology for the removal and storage of 85Kr. One of the main concerns with storage of cryogenically separated 85Kr in stainless steel canisters at elevated pressures (the baseline approach) is the Rb that is formed as the 85Kr decays. The use of MOFs augments this technology in two ways. First, it allows more gas to be stored in the canister at lower pressures. Second, the decay product Rb would be isolated from the metal canister, since it would be in the MOF structures, thereby reducing the corrosion concerns. In this regard, it would be beneficial to find a novel MOF that could remove low concentration Xe and Kr from air at relatively moderate temperatures in order to separate and store them, but better yet if there is sufficient specificity that the two could be separated from each other.

elements.content: Although research to date is somewhat limited with regard to noble gase adsorption, storage of these gases was demonstrated with some MOFs. Recently, we reported that Ni/DOBDC has a Xe capacity of 4.16 mol/kg at 1 bar and 298 K, which is higher than that of a charcoal carbon, and we also showed that we can swith the Xe/Kr selectivity for a microporous MOF by adjusting temperatures. Greathouse et al. used grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation to investigate Xe and Kr separation in IRMOF-1. Ryan and Snurr et al. studied Xe and Kr separation in several other MOFs also using a GCMC simulation method. Additional simulation work on screening the Xe/Kr selectivity for 137 000 hypothetical MOFs has also recently been published by Snurr’s group. They found that the MOFs with polar functional groups tend to have higher Xe/Kr selectivities compared to those that do not have polar functional groups. Moreover, the Xe/Kr selectivity is maximized when the MOF structures have pore morphologies resembling tubes of uniform pore width.

elements.content: Therefore, two benchmark MOFs, Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1, shown in Figure , are studied here for Xe and Kr adsorption using a dynamic breakthrough column method. The two MOFs were selected due to several reasons. First of all, both MOFs contain unsaturated metal centers which are polar sites and believed to be favorable for Xe and Kr adsorption. Second, the Ni/DOBDC was known to have high hydrothermal stability and higher Xe capacity than benchmark activated carbon. Third, the HKUST-1 has pores with a small aperture (5 Å) and pores with a larger diameter (15 Å) in the center, while the Ni/DOBDC has a uniform cylindrical pore with a size of 11 Å. It is interesting to investigate the effects of pore morphology on Xe/Kr selectivity for MOFs using experiment technique besides the simulation study. In this paper, Xe and Kr capacities and selectivities for the two MOFs were compared with those of an activated carbon. In addition, low concentrations of Xe and Kr adsorption from air were performed on the Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1 to investigate the potential of using these MOFs in real applications.

elements.content: The Ni/DOBDC was synthesized following a procedure reported in the literature. Briefly, a solution of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (1.486 g, 7.5 mmol) in THF (25 mL) and a solution of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (3.733 g, 15 mmol) in water (25 mL) were combined in a Teflon-lined insert of 100 mL volume. The insert was put into an autoclave, sealed, and reacted for 3 days at 110 °C in a preheated furnace. Filtration yielded 3.169 g of a yellowish fine crystalline product that was washed three times with water (50–100 mL) and dried in air at 85 °C under vacuum. HKUST-1 was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as it is. The charcoal activated carbon was U.S. Filter 1230C coconut shell activated carbon, and they are in pellet shape with sizes of about 1–2 mm.
elements.clean_text:
Experiment and Apparatus

Materials Synthesis and Preparation

The Ni/DOBDC was synthesized following a procedure reported in the literature. Briefly, a solution of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (1.486 g, 7.5 mmol) in THF (25 mL) and a solution of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (3.733 g, 15 mmol) in water (25 mL) were combined in a Teflon-lined insert of 100 mL volume. The insert was put into an autoclave, sealed, and reacted for 3 days at 110 °C in a preheated furnace. Filtration yielded 3.169 g of a yellowish fine crystalline product that was washed three times with water (50-100 mL) and dried in air at 85 °C under vacuum. HKUST-1 was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as it is. The charcoal activated carbon was U.S. Filter 1230C coconut shell activated carbon, and they are in pellet shape with sizes of about 1-2 mm.

elements.content: To minimize pressure drop and prevent potential contamination to the pipelines, MOF pellets were used for the breakthrough experiments. The Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1 pellets were formed through two steps. First, a powder sample with no binder was pressed into a disk under 12 MPa for 5 min. Then, the disk was carefully broken and the fragments were sieved for 20–30 mesh (600–850 um) pellets. The two-step procedure was repeated to make more pellets when necessary. Surface areas for the pellet samples were reported in the and our results show that the surface areas of the pellets decreased slightly compared to the powder samples for MOFs. However, the gas adsorption properties for the pellet samples are similar to their powder predecessors.

elements.content: The Xe and Kr breakthrough curves were measured for the Ni/DOBDC, HKUST-1, and activated carbon using a dynamic sorption analyzer (ARBC, Hiden Analytical Ltd., Warrington, U.K.) shown in Figure . Prior to gas adsorption experiments, the samples were regenerated by heating at certain temperatures in situ under helium purge for 15 h (). The sample was purged with He before and again after Xe and Kr breakthrough experiments. This procedure is applied throughout all the tested samples. In a typical pure Xe/Kr breakthrough experiment, a gas mixture with a total flow rate of 25 sccm and a total pressure of 1 bar flows through the adsorption bed. For a Xe and Kr mixture, a total flow rate of 50 sccm and a total pressure of 1 bar were used. Similarly, for the separation of Xe (1000 ppm Xe in Air) and Kr (1000 ppm Kr in air) from air, a flow rate of 20 sccm at 1 bar was used. The same setting was also applied to a separation of Xe (400 ppm) and Kr (40 ppm) mixture from air.

elements.content: The Pure Xe and Kr breakthrough curves for the Ni/DOBDC sample were shown in Figure . It is clear that the retention time of Xe is longer than that of Kr. In other words, the Ni/DOBDC can adsorb more Xe than Kr as expected. The Xe and Kr capacities for the Ni/DOBDC and other materials can be calculated by integrating the areas above the breakthrough curves as shown in our previous paper. The Xe and Kr dynamic capacities for all the materials at 1 bar and 25 °C were calculated and summarized in Figure . The results for the Ni/DOBDC and activated carbon are in agreement with the pure gas isotherms obtained using a static method. Both MOFs preferably adsorbed Xe over Kr because of larger polarizability of Xe enhancing the interactions with polarizable adsorbents. The Ni/DOBDC has the highest dynamic Xe capacity followed by the activated carbon and HKUST-1. In contrast, the activated carbon has the highest dynamic Kr capacity followed by the HKUST-1 and the Ni/DOBDC. Activated carbon is usually considered to be a benchmark adsorbent for Xe and Kr removal. The Ni/DOBDC can adsorb more Xe but less Kr than the activated carbon, which may indicate that the Ni/DOBDC has a higher Xe/Kr selectivity than that of the activated carbon. It is interesting to mention that the Xe and Kr capacities for the tested samples are not directly related with the surface areas (see ).

Results and Discussion

Pure Xe and Kr Breakthrough

The Pure Xe and Kr breakthrough curves for the Ni/DOBDC sample were shown in Figure . It is clear that the retention time of Xe is longer than that of Kr. In other words, the Ni/DOBDC can adsorb more Xe than Kr as expected. The Xe and Kr capacities for the Ni/DOBDC and other materials can be calculated by integrating the areas above the breakthrough curves as shown in our previous paper. The Xe and Kr dynamic capacities for all the materials at 1 bar and 25 °C were calculated and summarized in Figure . The results for the Ni/DOBDC and activated carbon are in agreement with the pure gas isotherms obtained using a static method. Both MOFs preferably adsorbed Xe over Kr because of larger polarizability of Xe enhancing the interactions with polarizable adsorbents. The Ni/DOBDC has the highest dynamic Xe capacity followed by the activated carbon and HKUST-1. In contrast, the activated carbon has the highest dynamic Kr capacity followed by the HKUST-1 and the Ni/DOBDC. Activated carbon is usually considered to be a benchmark adsorbent for Xe and Kr removal. The Ni/DOBDC can adsorb more Xe but less Kr than the activated carbon, which may indicate that the Ni/DOBDC has a higher Xe/Kr selectivity than that of the activated carbon. It is interesting to mention that the Xe and Kr capacities for the tested samples are not directly related with the surface areas (see ).

elements.content: Similarly, Xe and Kr mixtures with different compositions (Xe/Kr = 20:80, 50:50, 80:20) were executed (see experimental details in ). For the Ni/DOBDC, Xe and Kr (20:80) breakthrough results are shown in Figure as an example. In brief, Ni/DOBDC adsorbs Xe preferentially over Kr, which can be verified by the roll-up in the Kr breakthrough curve. Besides the partial effect from the change of volumetric flow rate, the roll-up phenomenon is mainly caused by the displacement of Kr by Xe, which has a stronger affinity to the Ni/DOBDC. Therefore, the effluent Kr concentration surpassed its concentration in the feed. After the Ni/DOBDC was saturated with Xe, the Kr effluent composition decreased and gradually matched the feed composition.

elements.content: Based on eq , Xe/Kr selectivities for all the samples under different Xe and Kr compositions were determined and compared in Figure . The Xe/Kr selectivities obtained here through a dynamic breakthrough method are much lower than what were predicted by Ryan et al. using GCMC simulation. For example, the Xe/Kr (20:80) selectivity for the HKUST-1 under 1 bar obtained in Ryan et al. simulation research is 8.1, while the Xe/Kr (20:80) selectivity was determined to be 2.6 for the HKUST-1 in this study. Besides the possible defects in the HKUST-1 sample used in this study, the likely reason is that the calculated selectivities from molecular simulation are theoretical equilibrium selectivities, while the measured selectivities in this study are combinations of both the equilibrium and kinetic selectivities. The two selectivities follow opposite trends for Xe and Kr adsorption in MOFs, because Xe molecules have higher polarizability but smaller diffusivity compared to Kr molecules. Notice that the Xe/Kr selectivities we obtained throughout this research are overall selectivities that include both the equilibrium and kinetic selectivities. Our Xe/Kr selectivities for both the Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1 agree fairly well with those reported in a recent publication in which permeation selectivities were calculated using GCMC and molecular dynamics simulations.

elements.content: Another interesting phenomenon is that the Ni/DOBDC has higher Xe/Kr selectivities than the HKUST-1 at all compositions. Due to the high densities of unsaturated metal centers, the Ni/DOBDC is expected to have a larger Xe capacity than the HKUST-1. However, HKUST-1 can adsorb a little bit more Kr than the Ni/DOBDC, which leads to smaller Xe/Kr selectivity for the HKUST-1. This can be verified from simulation work by Snurr and co-workers that MOFs with uniform pores tend to have higher Xe/Kr selectivities than those MOFs with bottleneck pores, in other words, large cavities connected by small openings channels. Our experimental results are consistent with the simulation results in the literature. A recent simulation study showed that at low loadings energetic effects are important and Xe molecules are favored to be adsorbed. At high loadings, entropic effects favoring the adsorption of Kr. Therefore, if a MOF has large cavities connected by narrow windows it is expected to see lower selectivity than a similar MOF with uniform pore sizes especially at high pressures.

A total of 1000 ppm Xe balanced with air (N2, 78%; O2, 21%; Ar, 0.9%; CO2, 0.03%; etc.) and a total of 1000 ppm Kr balanced with air were selected as two target gases to represent low concentration Xe and Kr in waste air streams. Before the breakthrough experiments, the bed was purged with He for 10 min, and then He was switched to the target gas mixtures to start the breakthrough experiment.

elements.content: For the Ni/DOBDC, N2 and O2 break through almost instantly, while Xe remains in the adsorption bed for about 10 min, which is also longer than CO2 (see ). It appears that Kr will break through at a slightly longer time compared to N2 and O2. The Xe capacity for the Ni/DOBDC at 25 °C and 1000 ppm was determined to be 9.3 mmol/kg (0.12 wt %) using the breakthrough method. Similarly, the Kr capacity for the Ni/DOBDC at 25 °C and 1000 ppm was determined to be 1.8 mmol/kg (0.015 wt %) using the breakthrough method. Again, Ni/DOBDC selectively adsorbs Xe over Kr as seen in Figure , but it appears that the difference was enlarged at a low concentration because the Xe/Kr selectivity of the Ni/DOBDC increased to about 5.3 when the concentration of Xe is 1000 ppm, and this result is consistent with what was reported in the literature.

Conclusions

In summary, both the Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1 have high capacities of Xe and Kr. The Xe/Kr overall selectivities, which combine the equilibrium and kinetic selectivities, decrease with increases of Xe concentrations in the mixtures for both MOFs and increase with decrease of partial pressures of Xe and Kr in the mixtures for the Ni/DOBDC. The Ni/DOBDC has higher Xe capacities and larger Xe/Kr selectivities compared to the benchmark activated carbon. In addition, the Ni/DOBDC has higher Xe/Kr selectivities than those of the HKUST-1, which is probably due to their different pore morphologies. The uniform cylindrical pores in the Ni/DOBDC are believed to be favorable to maximize the Xe/Kr selectivity. The Ni/DOBDC and HKUST-1 can selectively adsorb Xe and Kr from air even at ppm level concentrations. The Ni/DOBDC has a Xe capacity of 9.3 mmol/kg when the concentration of Xe is 1000 ppm in air. More importantly, for the first time our experimental results show that the Ni/DOBDC is able to separate 400 ppm Xe from 40 ppm Kr mixture in air with a Xe/Kr overall selectivity of 7.3. These results show that the Ni/DOBDC is a promising MOF to be used in radioactive air stream treatments.
